Augustine (PhD) Rm 2P15 School of Anatomical Sciences, Faculty of Health Sciences University of the Witwatersrand tanya.augustine@wits.ac.za Disclaimer • Lecture is a guideline only. Baltimore, MD: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins; 2006 • Anthony L. Mescher, Junqueira’s basic histology, 13th edition, 2013. • OlyVIA image viewer software – School of Anatomical Sciences • www.lab.anhb.uwa.edu.au/mb140 Specific outcomes • Identify and describe the structure and function of: o The kidney:  The cortex (including the renal corpuscle and associated tubules)  The medulla o The urinary bladder (epithelium only → see primary tissues – epithelium above) • Describe the blood supply of the kidney • Describe the filtration apparatus and juxtaglomerular apparatus of the kidney Introduction • The urinary system consists of: • Paired kidneys • Paired ureters • Urinary bladder • Urethra • The urinary system functions in: conserve fluid & electrolytes; remove metabolic waste; endocrine organ transport urine to the bladder temporary storage transport urine to the exterior Organisation www.cancer.gov Kidney – general structure • Renal capsule • Hilum & renal pelvis • Parenchyma • Cortex • Renal corpuscles + associated tubules • Medullary rays • Medulla • Selected tubules arranged in pyramids • Renal columns • Interstitial cells • Lobes & lobules Medullary rays Adapted from McBride, J.M. (2016). Embryology, Anatomy, and Histology of the Kidney. In: Hansel, D., Kane, C., Paner, G., Chang, S. (eds) The Kidney. Springer, New York, NY. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-1-4939-3286-3_1 Kidney – general structure • Parenchyma • Cortex • Renal corpuscles + associated tubules • Medullary rays • Medulla • Selected tubules arranged in pyramids • Renal columns Ross and Pawlina, 2006 Nephron • Structural & functional unit • Consists of: • Renal corpuscle • Glomerulus surrounded by Bowman’s capsule • Functions in creating ultrafiltrate • Proximal thick segment • Proximal convoluted tubule (pars convoluta) • Proximal straight tubule (pars recta)/thick segment loop of Henle • Thin segment • Thin part of the loop of Henle • Distal thick segment • Distal straight tubule (pars recta) • Distal convoluted tubule (pars convoluta) Junqueira and Carneiro, 2002 Nephron Junqueira and Carneiro, 2002 Ross and Pawlina, 2006 • Consist of glomerular capillaries + Bowman’s capsule • Filtration apparatus (glomerular filtration barrier): • Endothelium of the glomerular capillaries • Glomerular basement membrane • Visceral layer of Bowman’s capsule Junqueira and Carneiro, 2002 Renal corpuscle - filtration • Endothelium of the glomerular capillaries • Fenestrations without diaphragms • Glomerular basement membrane • Joint product of the endothelium & visceral layer of Bowman’s capsule • Type IV collagen, laminin, proteoglycans, glycoproteins … • Visceral layer of Bowman’s capsule • Cells are termed podocytes • Podocytes extend processes around capillaries with secondary processes termed pedicels Junqueira and Carneiro, 2002 Filtration apparatusUltrafiltrate • Urinary space is the receptacle for the ultrafiltrate • Urinary space is continuous with the proximal convoluted tubule • Encased by the parietal layer of Bowman’s capsule Junqueira and Carneiro, 2002 Clinical correlation • Albuminuria • Presence of significant amounts of albumin the urine indicate damage to the glomerular basement membrane • Diabetic nephropathy • Number of anionic sites in the glomerular basement membrane can be significantly reduced Healthy filtration barrier, Junqueira and Carneiro, 2002 • Vascular pole: • Afferent & efferent arterioles • Additional cell type: • Mesangial (lacis) cells (fxn?) • Urinary pole: • Urinary space continuous with proximal convoluted tubule Junqueira and Carneiro, 2002 Renal corpuscle -poles Juxtaglomerular apparatus • Consists of: • Juxtaglomerular cells • Modified cells of the afferent arteriole • Contain secretory granules • Renin (fxn?) • Macula densa • Terminal portion of distal straight tubule (note cell shape) • Monitor Na+ concentration and regulate glomerular filtration rate & release of renin • Extraglomerular mesangial cells • May also contribute to regulation of glomerular distension Junqueira and Carneiro, 2002 University of Western Australia http://lecannabiculteur.free.fr The proximal tubule • Proximal convoluted tubule • Initial & major site of reabsorption • Specialised epithelial cells • Cuboidal cells with a brush border • Junctional complex with tight junctions & zonula adherens • Lateral membrane folds (plicae) • Basal striations with mitochondria • Proximal straight tubule • Similar, shorter, less well developed brush border, fewer lateral and basolateral processes • Not as specialised for reabsorption Junqueira and Carneiro, 2002 The thin segment of the Loop of Henle • Varies depending on the location of the nephron – related to fxn • Four types of epithelial cells: • Type I & Type IV • Simple squamous epithelium • Type II • Low cuboidal epithelium with blunt microvilli • Type III • Simple squamous epithelium with few microvilli Junqueira and Carneiro, 2002 The distal tubule • Distal straight tubule: • Thick ascending part of the loop of Henle • Distal convoluted tubule: • Cuboidal cells with lack of brush border • Mitochondria found basal striations Junqueira and Carneiro, 2002 Collecting tubules and Collecting ducts Junqueira and Carneiro, 2002 • Squamous to cuboidal to columnar epithelium as ducts increase in size • Can be distinguished from PT/DT by clear cell boundaries • Two cell types: • Light cells: pale-staining with basal-infoldings,. Single cilium, few short microvilli. • Dark cells: few, with cytoplasmic apical folds and numerous mitochondria Ross and Pawlina, 2006 Excretory passages • Collecting ducts exit at the area cribrosa • Series of excretory passages till the urinary bladder: • Transitional epithelium • Urethra • Male ~20cm in 3 segments: • Prostatic urethra lined with transitional epithelium • Membranous urethra lined with stratified or pseudostratified columnar epithelium • Penile urethra lined with pseudostratified epithelium that becomes stratified squamous epithelium • Female ~3-5cm: • lined with pseudostratified epithelium that becomes stratified squamous epithelium Ross and Pawlina, 2006 Recap Medullary rays
